column1: #Text=Emails exchanged among United States Air Force officials regarding a USD$23 billion dollar deal with aircraft manufacturer Boeing have been entered into the public record.
#Text=Senator John McCain (R-AZ) entered them into the Congressional Record during a speech last week against the now-cancelled deal to lease 100 mid-air tanker aircraft from Boeing.
#Text=Congressional lawmakers rejected the proposal in October, although industry experts say the deal had been killed by the Pentagon because of reports stating that the deal had favored Boeing.
#Text=Senator McCain has been the deal's most vocal critic.
#Text=The original negotiations with Boeing were over a no-bid contract.
#Text=Such contracts are often justified by the speed they offer, eliminating a preliminary bid and selection round that may last months.
#Text=However, no-bid contracts are only open to the company selected by the procuring agency.
#Text=This leaves no-bid contracts open to accusations of conflicts of interest among the procurement personnel.

#Text=Such accusations have previously been leveled against Vice President Dick Cheney for a no-bid contract to Halliburton, and are now being made against senior Air Force officials for choosing Boeing to replace its tanker fleet.
#Text=In the released emails, Air Force officials responsible for the awarding of contracts appear biased against Boeing's main competitor, Airbus and its CEO Ralph Crosby.
#Text=Airbus is owned by European Aeronautic Defense & Space Company (EADS).
#Text=Airbus manufacturers a number of passenger and military aircraft and has gained market share in passenger aircraft over Boeing in recent years.
#Text=The following is a sequential email exchange regarding Airbus as recorded in the Congressional Record:
#Text=:Special Asst. to the Secretary and Director of Air Force Communications Bill Bodie: "We don't have to turn the other cheek, you know.

column3: #Text=:Secretary of the Air Force James Roche: No, Sir, save it and blow him away.
#Text=:Civilian Deputy Undersecretary of the Air Force for Acquisition Darleen Druyun: I read with disgust the article on Airbus tankers from the new EADS CEO of North America.
#Text=:Secretary of the Air Force James Roche: Oy.

#Text=An email from Burkhardt & Associates to James Roche advises the Secretary to release fiscal numbers favorable to Boeing, apparently regardless of the facts: I'd distribute a one page memo saying the per plane cost of the lease will not be greater than x and have x be less than the last lease Boeing did for some commercial entity--or that x is y dollars less than the cost of a new tanker," it said.

column1: #Text=An additional email by Roche provides a stark contrast to his criticism of Airbus, as he talks to Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Acquisition Marvin Sambur about Boeing, saying, "I love Ya, Big Guy.

#Text=Give it to the Blue Eyed Arabs of the North (the expression we used for Boeing).

#Text=GovExec.com quotes a Senate aide" as saying: "The House language of the spending bill ignores an analysis of alternatives called for in last year's authorizing language and by Pentagon Acquisition Director Michael Wynne and the DSB.
#Text=The activist organization the Project on Government Oversight has called it a textbook case of favoritism to a single defense contractor."

column1: #Text=Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Acquisition Marvin Sambur defended the Air Force's exclusive consideration of Boeing, saying, "This was not a competitive bid process.
